text: [Music]
Someone once asked me, you know, why why
did you choose to write about Middle
Eastern men and not Middle Eastern
women? Um, I don't I I don't know their
reality. I don't know any women in Iran
who have had to wear um the Chador and
Rouser, you know. Um I don't know women
of that era. My mother, you know, was in
Iran last in the 70s at the um in in the
height of the sha, you know, and she in
the summers she would go shopping in
Milan and you know that they were quite
western at that point. Um, I I don't
know what it's like for Middle Eastern
women today, but from what I've heard,
um, you know, Iran is a from what I've
heard, they're they're a little bit
perplexed by the image of Iranian women
as incredibly downtrodden. There's lots
of jokes and proverbs and Farsy about
how, you know, Middle Eastern or Iranian
women are this force um, and the real
force of the household. Um, and I tend
to believe in that. Um, obviously what's
happened since the revolution, it's been
horrible for women and and you know,
incredible human rights violations that
have been specifically targeting um,
women.
But I think their day-to-day reality is
different and and Iran is a country
where the majority of um, people in
univers the majority of university
students are are women. I think that is
interesting um in spite of what's been
happening there. So, it's tricky to
speak on that. Um maybe that's part of
why I chose to focus on Middle Eastern
men.
Um
they're I have an easier time imagining
what it's like for them. Um it's there
it's a more complicated mixed bag with
what's happening with women.
